verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Introductory divine speech, consistent with previous chapters.

verses.text: “Send men to spy out the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the children of Israel. From each tribe of their fathers you shall send a man, every one a chief among them.”
verses.comment: ‘Spy out’ translated as ‘explore’; ‘children of Israel’ retained for accuracy.

verses.text: So Moses sent them from the Wilderness of Paran, according to the command of the LORD, all of them men who were heads of the children of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Wilderness of Paran’ is maintained in name; ‘men who were heads’ clarified as leaders.

verses.text: These were their names: from the tribe of Reuben, Shammua the son of Zaccur;
verses.comment: List begins, kept literal.

verses.text: From the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat the son of Hori;
verses.comment: Names spelled as per common transliteration.

verses.text: From the tribe of Judah, Caleb the son of Jephunneh;
verses.comment: Caleb highlighted; consistent with traditions.

verses.text: From the tribe of Issachar, Igal the son of Joseph;
verses.comment: Literal rendering.

verses.text: From the tribe of Ephraim, Hoshea the son of Nun;
verses.comment: Hoshea later renamed Joshua; name retained as in original.

verses.text: From the tribe of Benjamin, Palti the son of Raphu;
verses.comment: Name and tribal order preserved.

verses.text: From the tribe of Zebulun, Gaddiel the son of Sodi;
verses.comment: Ancient names; transliteration taken from Hebrew.

verses.text: From the tribe of Joseph, that is, from the tribe of Manasseh, Gaddi the son of Susi;
verses.comment: Clarifies which part of Joseph's descendants; ‘that is’ added for modern clarity.

verses.text: From the tribe of Dan, Ammiel the son of Gemalli;
From the tribe of Asher, Sethur the son of Michael;
From the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi the son of Vophsi;
From the tribe of Gad, Geuel the son of Machi.
These were the names of the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land. And Moses called Hoshea the son of Nun Joshua.
verses.comment: Explains Joshua's name change within the narrative.

verses.text: Moses sent them to spy out the land of Canaan, and said to them, “Go up this way into the Negev, and go up into the hill country.
verses.comment: ‘Negev’ is retained as a geographic marker.

verses.text: See what the land is like and whether the people who dwell in it are strong or weak, few or many.
verses.comment: ‘See what the land is like’ kept literal for clarity.

verses.text: And whether the land they dwell in is good or bad, and whether the cities they live in are like camps or strongholds.
verses.comment: ‘Camps or strongholds’ makes a clear distinction between settlements.

verses.text: And whether the land is rich or poor, whether there are trees in it or not. Be courageous and bring back some of the fruit of the land.” (Now the time was the season of the first ripe grapes.)
verses.comment: Parenthetical statement retained as in original.

verses.text: So they went up and spied out the land from the Wilderness of Zin to Rehob, near Lebo-hamath.
verses.comment: Geographic markers preserved, some place names modernized for consistency.

verses.text: They went up through the Negev and came to Hebron; Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, the descendants of Anak, were there. (Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)
verses.comment: Parenthetical statement kept for historical context.

verses.text: They came to the Valley of Eshcol and cut off a branch with a single cluster of grapes. They carried it on a pole between two of them, together with some pomegranates and figs.
verses.comment: Imagery retained from original.

verses.text: That place was called the Valley of Eshcol because of the cluster that the children of Israel cut off there.
verses.comment: Historical naming reason preserved.

verses.text: They returned from spying out the land after forty days.
verses.comment: Duration emphasized as in original.

verses.text: They came back to Moses, Aaron, and all the congregation of the children of Israel in the Wilderness of Paran at Kadesh. They brought back word to them and to the whole congregation, and showed them the fruit of the land.
verses.comment: ‘Congregation’ retained to refer to the assembly of Israel.

verses.text: They told him, “We came to the land where you sent us. It truly flows with milk and honey, and this is its fruit.
verses.comment: ‘Flows with milk and honey’ is a biblical idiom preserved.

verses.text: However, the people who dwell in the land are strong, and the cities are fortified and very large. Moreover, we saw the descendants of Anak there.
verses.comment: ‘Descendants of Anak’ retained as in Hebrew.

verses.text: The Amalekites dwell in the land of the Negev. The Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites dwell in the hill country. The Canaanites dwell by the sea and along the Jordan.
verses.comment: Tribal distribution clarified; proper nouns retained.

verses.text: Caleb quieted the people before Moses and said, “Let us go up at once and occupy it, for we are well able to overcome it.”
verses.comment: Caleb quoted for faithfulness and initiative.

verses.text: But the men who had gone up with him said, “We are not able to go up against the people, for they are stronger than we are.”

So they brought up a bad report of the land that they had scouted to the children of Israel, saying, “The land, through which we have gone to spy it out, is a land that devours its inhabitants, and all the people whom we saw in it are of great stature.
verses.comment: ‘Devours its inhabitants’ idiom retained; ‘bad report’ accurate translation.

verses.text: And there we saw the Nephilim (the sons of Anak, who come from the Nephilim), and we seemed to ourselves like grasshoppers, and so we seemed to them.”
verses.comment: ‘Nephilim’ left untranslated to match scholarly practice. ‘Grasshoppers’ captures the Hebrew metaphor accurately.
